Research Introduction

Restoring Human Capability

Welcome to the Bionic Arm Project — an innovative and affordable prosthetic solution designed to restore essential hand functions for individuals with upper-limb amputations in Sri Lanka.

Our bionic arm uses Electromyography (EMG) sensors to read muscle activity and convert those signals into smooth, intuitive hand movements.

The system is built using 3D-printed components, servo motors, and a microcontroller-based control system, offering reliable gripping, holding, and everyday functionality.

Designed with a focus on cost-effectiveness, comfort, and local manufacturability, this solution aims to make advanced prosthetic technology accessible to low-resource communities.

Advanced Prosthetic Technology

EMG-controlled precision movement

EMG
Research Focus

Problem & Objectives

Addressing the critical gap in prosthetic accessibility through innovative engineering

High Cost of Prosthetics

Imported prosthetic devices cost up to LKR 1,000,000, making them inaccessible to most amputees in Sri Lanka.

Limited Accessibility

Many amputees lack access to advanced prosthetic technology due to geographical and economic barriers.

Dependency on Imports

Sri Lanka heavily relies on foreign prosthetic devices, with limited local manufacturing capabilities.

Research Objectives

1

Design and develop an affordable EMG-controlled bionic arm

2

Utilize 3D printing for lightweight and customizable components

3

Implement EMG signal processing for intuitive control

4

Create a locally manufacturable solution for Sri Lankan amputees

5

Validate functionality through prototype testing and user feedback

Key Advantages

Project Benefits

Empowering users to regain independence, confidence, and improved quality of life

Increased Independence

Allows amputees to perform day-to-day tasks such as gripping a glass, holding tools, and handling objects.

Affordable Alternative

Cost is around LKR 150,000, significantly cheaper than imported prosthetic hands costing up to LKR 1,000,000.

Locally Manufactured

Reduces dependency on foreign devices and supports local innovation in Sri Lanka.

User-Friendly & Comfortable

Lightweight 3D-printed structure and ergonomic design for long-term wear and natural movement.

Reliable Technology

EMG signal detection + microcontroller + servo motors ensure precise and responsive hand motion.

Working Principle

How It Works

From muscle signal to prosthetic movement in milliseconds

1

Muscle Signal

EMG sensors detect electrical signals from muscle contractions

2

Signal Processing

Microcontroller processes and filters the EMG data

3

Motor Actuation

Servo motors receive commands to move specific fingers

4

Finger Movement

Prosthetic fingers perform gripping and holding actions
